prompt.p: A 30-year-old man presents with a neck lump. The fine-needle aspiration biopsy is positive and a thyroid malignancy is suspected.
What is the most likely type of thyroid malignancy to occur in young people?

modalFeedback.p: Option E is Correct. Papillary malignancies make up 70% of thyroid carcinomas and tend to occur in young people, with local spread and sometimes lung/bone secondaries. The other types are rare.
Option A is Incorrect. Anaplastic malignancies are rare and typically occur in the elderly. They respond poorly to treatment.
Option B is Incorrect. Follicular malignancies are, however, the next most common type of thyroid carcinoma after papillary. They make up 20% of all thyroid carcinomas.
Option C is Incorrect. Lymphoma makes up approximately 5% of all thyroid carcinomas.
Option D is Incorrect. Medullary malignancies make up approximately 5% of all thyroid carcinomas. They occur sporadically or as part of the multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome.
